name: Roman Coin
fact: Roman coins often show the faces of emperors and help archaeologists date ancient settlements.
credit: Illustration stored in assets: Roman Coin

name: Egyptian Amulet
fact: Amulets from ancient Egypt were worn for protection and were buried with mummies for good luck in the afterlife.
credit: Illustration stored in assets: Egyptian Amulet

name: Greek Vase
fact: Painted Greek vases tell stories from mythology and show how ancient Greeks lived and worked.
credit: Illustration stored in assets: Greek Vase

name: Mayan Mask
fact: Mayan masks were used in ceremonies to honor gods, celebrate kings, and represent animals or ancestors.
credit: Illustration stored in assets: Mayan Mask

name: Incan Quipu
fact: A quipu is made of knotted cords that Incan record keepers used to track numbers like taxes and harvests.
credit: Illustration stored in assets: Incan Quipu

name: Mesopotamian Tablet
fact: Clay tablets with cuneiform writing from Mesopotamia hold some of the oldest written stories and laws.
credit: Illustration stored in assets: Mesopotamian Tablet

name: Viking Brooch
fact: Viking brooches fastened heavy cloaks and were decorated with patterns showing Norse art styles.
credit: Illustration stored in assets: Viking Brooch

name: Terracotta Warrior
fact: Thousands of life-sized terracotta warriors were buried with China's first emperor to guard him in the afterlife.
credit: Illustration stored in assets: Terracotta Warrior

name: Native American Arrowhead
fact: Arrowheads made from stone or obsidian show where Indigenous peoples hunted and traded across North America.
credit: Illustration stored in assets: Native American Arrowhead

name: Medieval Knight Helmet
fact: This style of helmet, called a sallet, protected European knights during the late Middle Ages.
credit: Illustration stored in assets: Medieval Knight Helmet

name: Benin Bronze Plaque
fact: Benin bronzes from West Africa record the history of the Edo people and their royal court.
credit: Illustration stored in assets: Benin Bronze Plaque

name: Egyptian Sarcophagus
fact: Decorated sarcophagi protected mummies and were painted with scenes to guide the dead through the afterlife.
credit: Illustration stored in assets: Egyptian Sarcophagus

name: Aztec Calendar Stone
fact: The Aztec Sun Stone is carved with symbols showing how the Aztecs measured time and honored their gods.
credit: Illustration stored in assets: Aztec Calendar Stone

name: Indus Valley Seal
fact: Small seals from the Indus Valley have animals and symbols that may represent names or trade goods.
credit: Illustration stored in assets: Indus Valley Seal

name: Stone Age Hand Axe
fact: Hand axes are some of the oldest tools humans made and were used for cutting meat, wood, and plants.
credit: Illustration stored in assets: Stone Age Hand Axe

name: Babylonian Cylinder Seal
fact: Cylinder seals were rolled over wet clay to leave a picture signature that marked ownership or told stories.
credit: Illustration stored in assets: Babylonian Cylinder Seal

name: Celtic Torc
fact: A torc is a rigid neck ring worn by Celtic leaders to show status and skill in metalworking.
credit: Illustration stored in assets: Celtic Torc

name: Samurai Armor
fact: Samurai armor from Japan used layers of metal and lacquered leather to balance protection and movement.
credit: Illustration stored in assets: Samurai Armor

name: Aboriginal Boomerang
fact: Aboriginal Australian boomerangs were crafted for hunting, ceremony, and storytelling.
credit: Illustration stored in assets: Aboriginal Boomerang

name: Paleolithic Cave Painting
fact: Cave paintings like these bison from Altamira show how early humans observed animals and used natural pigments.
credit: Illustration stored in assets: Paleolithic Cave Painting
